document.docAuthor: Kim, Junggon, Kim, Young Jin, Lim, Jongok & Jung, Sunghoon
document.masterDocTitle: A new species of the genus Rhabdomiris (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Mirinae) from the Korean Peninsula, based on morphology and molecular data

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new species of the genus Rhabdomiris (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Miridae: Mirinae) from the Korean Peninsula, based on morphology and molecular data

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Cimex variegatus
Müller, 1776: 108
(junior primary homonym of
Cimex variegatus Poda, 1761
; Synonymized by Reuter, 1888:

subSubSection.paragraph:
252).
Cimex pulligo Harris, 1780: 89
(nomen oblitum; Synonymized by Stephens, 1829: 349).
Cimex quadripunctatus Villers, 1789: 535
(junior primary homonym of
Cimex quadripunctatus Müller, 1766
; Synonymized by
Reuter, 1888: 252).
Cimex ochromelas Gmelin, 1790: 2180
(junior primary homonym of
Cimex ochromelas Gmelin, 1790: 2165
).
Lygaeus striatellus Fabricius, 1794: 173
.
Calocoris striatellus Kerzhner, 1970: 141
.
Rhabdomiris striatellus Rosenzweig, 1997: 168
;
Zheng et al. 2004: 568
(Chinese record (?)).
Rhabdomiris striatellus wagneri Kerzhner & Schuh, 1998: 172
.

Diagnosis: Distinguished by body brownish and somewhat smaller; third antennal segment dark brown; frons pale brown with narrow longitudinal dark stripe; pronotum yellowish brown with distinctive four dark maculae in anterior part, patterns not connecting to dark band in posterior part, sometimes size of patterns variable, posterior part with dark brown band, dark band separated in middle part, posterior margin pale brown; scutellum entirely brown; mesoscutum dark brown ( Figs. 1D ); left paramere relatively not thick, angled dorsally, weakly projected near sensory lobe, process of sensory lobe relatively short and weakly rounded, lateral tooth small ( Figs. 4 A–B); right paramere narrow, hypophysis slightly short, its apex blunt ( Fig. 4C ); endosomal spicule as long as membranous lobe, broader from subapical part; lateral sclerite I triangular, tapered to apex; lateral sclerite II with tiny spinules in only upper and lateral part; medial sclerite shorter than membranous lobe ( Figs. 4 D–F); sclerotized ring oval; sclerotized perimeter of combined common oviduct and dorsal wall of genital chamber narrowly developed ( Fig. 4G ); lateral lobe of posterior wall distinctly developed, spine-like structure; dorsal structure largely developed, with distinct small spinules on the whole part ( Fig. 4H ).
Description: see Henry (2017) for detailed description.

FEMALE GENITALIA: sr oval, not closed to each other, spgc developed, not broad ( Fig. 4G ); irl not surpassing irs , irl broader than ds , with distinct small spinules, llb distinctly developed, ds oval and broadly developed, with small spinules on the whole part ( Fig. 4H ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. Genitalic structures of male and female of
Rhabdomiris striatellus
. A: left paramere in dorsal view; B: ditto , in lateral view; C: right paramere; D–F: endosoma; G: genital chamber; H: posterior wall; scale bar: 0.5mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Material Examined: [ CRBA ]
1♂ , Seva , Seva , Osona , Barcelona , Catalunya , Spain ,
21.v.1961
, J. Ribes leg. [CRBA-71208];
[ CRBA ]
2♂♂ 3♀♀ , Can Miqueldolca , Santa Coloma , Andorra la Vella , Andorra ,
15.vi.1993
, by Malaise (
01–15.vi.1993
), M. Goula leg. [CRBA-39626]
.

Distribution: Azerbaijan , Armenia , China , Iran , Turkey , Georgia , Europe (see Aukema & Rieger 1999 for detailed European distribution), North America. The record of this species to Korean fauna is deleted.

Remarks: Wagner (1974) mentioned the character state, markings on scutellum, to be variable in two types of
R. striatellus
(indicated as two subspecies,
Calocoris quadripunctatus quadripunctatus
and
C. quadripunctatus fasciatus
), even though all examined specimens in this study were consistent to have scutellum without any markings.
Zheng et al. (2004)
also reported the species as
R. striatellus
(without pictures), but it is suspected that the species is not
R. striatellus
, but
R. koreanus
sp. nov.
because it has scutellum with dark longitudinal stripe in accordance with the description (in Chinese). Henry (2017) recently provided detailed description of this species, including the ranges of variation of important characters.
